newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT - NYMEX consolidation depends on gasoline.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - NYMEX consolidation depends on gasoline.

text.p: ----------------- VIEWS FROM THE MARKET - JUNE 11 -------------
* NYMEX crude and products' near term oversold condition is stirring sentiment for a period of consolidation or even correction
* But analysts continue to eye it's downside structure for longer term direction.

NYMEX crude and products futures were seen stable on Wednesday but while the near term oversold condition stirred sentiment for a period of consolidation or even correction, analysts continued to eye it's downside structure.
"WTI (NYMEX crude) is in consolidation mode and finding support at $18.50 and resistance at $18.80-$19.00," Leslie Nicholas at GNI Research said.
"But the products will have to be watched today and if July gasoline breaks below $56 cents a one cent move to technical support at 55 cents is on the cards," he added.
"This would give a negative implication to the crude markets," Nicholas said.
Tony Machachek at Credit Lyonnais Rouse saw NYMEX coming in 10-15 cents a barrel higher on crude with products up around 0.25 cents a gallon.
"The market has moved so much to the downside recently and is looking increasingly oversold that we must be due a short-covering correction soon," Machachek said.
Fenella Graham at MeesPierson was more bearish saying the market remained soft with the preparation negative but saw any stability at these levels prompting short-covering
"We sold again yesterday at $18.90 and although Monday's selling extreme was subsequently covered the market remains soft and so we held onto the shorts," Graham said of crude.

"The story remains the same today, we must continue to sell the rallies unless prices remain above $18.70 leaving a buying extreme from yesterday's closing period, prompting us to start covering our shorts," she added.
NYMEX Crude and products futures eased in ACCESS trade, undercut by Tuesday's bearish, though as expected API report of growing U.S. stocks but were staging a recovery by late morning on Wednesday.
Graham added, "prices have recovered from last night's close "probably because the losses yesterday are now being seen as enough to take the bearish data into consideration.
On ACCESS, July crude futures traded down to $18.57 a barrel, 10 cents below Tuesday's settlement but recovered on Wednesday morning to stand around 10 cents up at $18.77 a barrel.

July gasoline fell 0.40 cents a gallon to 56 cents but here too the market recovered by over half a cent to stand at $56.60 cents a gallon. Heating oil rebounded to trade at 51.90 cents after dipping to 51.40 cents a gallon from a settlement of 51.65 cents.
- Colin Wooster, London Newsroom, +44 171 542 7456
